The Trump administration announced Monday that it will fully fund a $650 million federal grant for electrification of a San Francisco Bay Area train system that also would help California’s high-speed rail project.

The rail authority is fighting hard just for previous funding, let alone new federal funding. California Republicans are against federal funding, so it seems really unlikely, particularly so given the timeframe.
New appropriations funding will not be approved by July 1 2017.
It is next to impossible. I live where the train is expected to pass through and there is a lot of pushback. Not to mention with Trump, it is even more unlikely.
Dropping from 1 to zero because I'm realizing the federal government is going to be a lot less effective this year than I thought back in January.

Despite its commitment to intrastructure spending (hence 5% YES) I believe that the Trump administration will require further information on costs/budget particularly after Cal Repubs requested no Federal spending.
Trump is too ineffective to get something done this quickly. And a Democrat state is unlikely to be awarded one of the first major infrastructure projections under Trump.
TLDR: The new CR, the one that takes us from 4/29 through 9/30/17, specifically appropriates bupkis to California High Speed Rail as a matter of law.

Although this is an enormous infrastructure investment, the personal chemistry between Trump and California in general, and Trump and Brown in particular is too toxic for this project to have any legs. Add to that the stated intent of Trumps's USDOT to fund any new passenger rail starts, intercity and urban, make this a non-starter. Also the lack of consensus within California about the merits of the project and the cost work against it. Someday it might well happen but not in the current political climate.
California doesn't have enough clout in federal govt. to get this approved.

Cost over runs, poorly laid out budget, delays will only add to costs, Trump will most likely not approve initial proposal without serious reviews, and alternative transport with new Hyper Loop technology is much less expensive and feasible given concept has been proven to work.

Following aarongertler and because Trump and Republican legislators are not fond of heavily Democratic California. Also a shout out to Khalid's comment.

Although it is a high profile infrastructure project, it is controversial even in deep Blue California, and Trump and his Department of Transportation will not want to reward Governor Brown or the state's two Democratic senators with such an expensive accomplishment. The current administration, and the Congress seem to have it in for California. This project will be put on the back burner until there is a change in the composition of Congress and the Presidency.
USDOT just deferred making a decision on a more than $600M grant for the project until there is an audit conducted on the project.

The project has long been vilified by congressional Republicans, particularly by House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Bakersfield), who has called it a “boondoggle” that was “doomed to fail from the start.”

Budget for this project is out of control. If the growing costs don't kill this project, then new advances in more efficient and safer alternative travel should.
Major infrastructure package is highly unlikely to be approved ahead of ACA and Tax reform bills leaving the bullet train unfunded before July 1 2017

Under this administration, California is in line for federal funds two places behind Hell.  This will not be political.  You will know it isn't political because President Littlefingers will say it isn't.

The California congressional delegation is largely Democratic and the California state government is majority Democratic. There is no political upside for a Republican controlled federal government to do anything for California. It has nothing to do with policy, efficiency, environment, budget or even facts -- just sheer spite. That's the way things are now and the way they are likely to remain for awhile.

I think 25-1 odds are a fair starting point.  I don't want to underestimate the possibility that the Trump administration launches an all-out effort to fund infrastructure spending in the earliest months, as: 1) he appears to place a high priority on showing early action;  2) infrastructure spending is a high-probability way to fund jobs; and 3) some construction jobs would come with the project.  However, the opposition of the California Republican congressional delegation, the recent cost overruns, and the reports of lax cost controls ... and the resulting demands to audit the project .. are huge impediments to any federal funding being announced in the next 4 1/2 months.
With new Republican house and senate and CA's antagonism toward Trump, hard to see the funding approved.

As it was commented before, CA needs to have the back up of its congressional delegation for this kind of project, it requires a full blown support to get going forward. Right now, the support in Washington is not there, and CA cannot afford to raise the funds alone to get the project done.  A good thing with poor support!
Trump will punish CA wherever he possibly can. He says they're out of control... as they didn't vote for him.

Highly doubtful. You might think that California's congressional delegation would want to harvest some pork from DC, but that isn't the case here.
